https://blogs.wsj.com/indiarealtime/2011/12/28/russia-dismisses-bhagavad-gita-ban/?mod=google_news_blog |accessdate = 29 December 2011 |newspaper = [[Wall Street Journal]] |date = 29 December 2011 }} *{{cite news |title = Russian court says key text of Hare Krishna movement is not 'extremist' |url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/russian-court-to-consider-ban-on-key-text-of-hare-krishna-movement/2011/12/28/gIQA1GUgLP_story.html |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/64JDsoJUk?url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/russian-court-to-consider-ban-on-key-text-of-hare-krishna-movement/2011/12/28/gIQA1GUgLP_story.html |archivedate = 30 December 2011 |accessdate = 29 December 2011 |newspaper = [[The Washington Post]] |date = 28 December 2011 |agency = [[Associated Press]] |deadurl = yes |df = dmy }}</ref>
===Appeal (March 2012)=== On January 26, 2012, the Tomsk prosecutor's office appealed the court's refusal to declare the Russian ''Bhagavad Gita As It Is'' an extremist text in a superior court, insisting that the book should be banned,<ref name=TOI-APP>{{cite news|title=Gita verdict: Russian prosecutors planning to file appeal|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-01-26/europe/30666187_1_gita-verdict-social-discord-and-hatred-appeal|accessdate=26 January 2012|newspaper=[[The Times of India]]|date=26 January 2012}}</ref><ref name=RIA-APP>{{cite news |title=Ban Only Russian Comment in Hindu Holy Book – Prosecutors |url=http://en.ria.ru/russia/20120216/171341942.html |accessdate=16 February 2012 |date=16 February 2012 |agency=[[RIA Novosti]]}}</ref> and asking for more time.<ref name=ET-APP>{{cite news|title=Russian prosecutors to move higher court seeking Gita ban |url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/politics/nation/russian-prosecutors-to-move-higher-court-seeking-gita-ban/articleshow/11640077.cms|accessdate=26 January 2012|newspaper=[[The Economic Times]]|date=26 January 2012}} {{Dead link|date=September 2013|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref>
The prosecutors insisted that the Russian translation of the book be banned as "extremist literature."<ref name=firstpost1>{{cite news|title=Gita verdict: Russian prosecutors planning to file appeal|url=http://www.firstpost.com/india/gita-verdict-russian-prosecutors-planning-to-file-appeal-194858.html|accessdate=26 January 2012|newspaper=[[The First Post]]|date=26 January 2012}}</ref> The appeal quoted Russian Foreign Ministry spokesman Alexander Lukashevich questioning the translated version, the authenticity of its linguistics as they relate to Hindu scripture, and "semantic distortions."<ref name="firstpost1"/>
The prosecutor general for Tomsk Vasily Voikin said, "When we have to deal with such materials, we are just bound to proceed with them. The law opposes extremism. When scholars say the text is of an extremist character, we just have to respond".<ref name=RASPI-APP>{{cite news|title=Prosecutor's office appeals adverse judgment in Bhagavad Gita case|url=http://rapsinews.com/judicial_news/20120126/259796779.html|accessdate=16 February 2012|date=1 February 2012|agency=RASPI}}</ref> The appeal was scheduled for hearing by the Tomsk regional court on March 6, 2012<ref>{{cite news|title=Appeal in Bhagavad Gita case to be heard in March|url=http://rapsinews.com/judicial_news/20120214/260191734.html|accessdate=14 February 2012|newspaper=RAPSI (Russian Legal Information Agency)|date=14 February 2012}}</ref> but was later rescheduled for March 20.<ref name=Hindu-20 />
On February 16, 2012, explaining the rationale behind the appeal, first deputy prosecutor general of Russia Alexander Buksman said in an interview during his visit to Tomsk that the public misunderstood the initial plea of prosecutor's office to have the ''Bhagavad Gita As It Is'' declared an extremist text. He stated that the prosecutor’s office sought a ban of the Russian version of the book’s commentaries rather than on the Hindu text itself, adding, "it’s important to discern gems from the chatter in this very case; the society’s perception of this issue is that prosecutors are standing against the concepts of this religion [Hinduism]. However, the problem is that the Russian translation has paragraphs that could be seen as promoting extremism; prosecutors started the case for that reason." Deputy prosecutor general of Russian in Siberia region Ivan Semchishyn confirmed, "That is why the prosecutor now has to stand up for his position in the appellate court".<ref name=RIA-APP /><ref name=newsru-proc>{{cite news|url=http://newsru.com/religy/16feb2012/bhagavad.html|script-title=ru:В Генпрокуратуре считают, что дело "Бхагавад-гиты" представляется в обществе искаженно|trans-title=The prosecutor's office believes that the "Bhagavad Gita" case is distorted in the community|newspaper=[[NEWSru.com]]|date=16 February 2012|language=Russian}}</ref>
On February 21, 2012, at a press conference at the [[Interfax]] office in Tomsk, [[Anti-cult movement|anti-cult]] activist [[Alexander Dvorkin]] stated that the "manifesto book of the Krishna Consciousness Society, ''Bhagavad Gita As It Is'', is not immediately related to the original, being a free and not quite skilled translation."<ref>{{cite news|title=Prosecutors' complaints in Bhagavad Gita book case legitimate – expert|url=http://www.interfax-religion.com/?act=news&div=9088|accessdate=21 February 2012|newspaper=Interfax|date=21 February 2012}}</ref>
In response to the appeal, the [[Vishwa Hindu Parishad]] (VHP), along with the [[International Society for Krishna Consciousness]] (ISKCON), stated that they would fight "internationally" against any threats to ban the Bhagavad Gita in Russia.<ref>{{cite news|title=VHP, Iskcon to fight against ban attempt on Gita|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-02-23/bhubaneswar/31090291_1_bhagavad-gita-ban-attempts|accessdate=23 February 2012|newspaper=Interfax|date=23 February 2012}}</ref>
===Dismissal of appeal (March 2012)=== Representative of the prosecution said that the district court incorrectly interpreted the definition of "extremism" when it claimed that it is necessary for it to contain calls to extremist activity which must be expressed in any kind of actions, pointing out that the law prohibits all propaganda that incites any kind of hatred.<ref name=Echo-Moskvy>{{cite news|title=Томский суд вновь отказал прокуратуре в запрете книги "Бхагавад-гита как она есть"|date=21 March 2012|author=[[Echo Moskvy]]|url=http://echo.msk.ru/news/870830-echo.html}}</ref><ref name=newsru-mar21>{{cite news|title=Суд в Томске вновь отказался признать экстремистской книгу "Бхагавад-гита как она есть"|date=21 March 2012|author=[[NEWSru]]|url=http://newsru.com/religy/21mar2012/bhagavad.html}}</ref>
On March 21, 2012, the appeal court upheld the decision of the lower court, rejecting the prosecutor's petition.<ref name=ITAR-TASS-2 /><ref name=NDTVxx>{{cite news|title=Russian court dismisses plea seeking ban on Gita|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/world/russian-court-dismisses-plea-seeking-ban-on-gita-188254|accessdate=21 March 2012|newspaper=[[NDTV]]|date=21 March 2012|agency=[[Press Trust of India]]}}</ref> On May 29, 2012, Tomsk regional prosecutor Vasily Voykin said that the prosecutor's office will no further appeal the court's refusal to declare ''Bhagavad Gita As It Is'' extremist.<ref>{{cite news|title=Prosecutors won't contest court refusal to declare 'Bhagavad Gita As It Is' extremist|url=http://rapsinews.com/judicial_news/20120529/263289348.html|accessdate=29 May 2012|newspaper=Russian Legal Information Agency|date=29 May 2012|agency=[[RIA Novosti]]}}</ref>
==Reaction to the trial==
===In India===
====Media==== Since December 17, 2011, when ''[[Indo-Asian News Service]]'' (IANS) issued a report by a staff writer Nallan Chakravarthi Bipindra (NC Bipindra) from Moscow about the proposed ''Bhagavad Gita'' ban in Russia, the event became breaking news in the [[Media of India|Indian printed and electronic media]], with over 600 publications, including editorials, in all major newspapers and TV news channels as of December 27, 2011.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/topic/Bhagavad-Gita|title=Topic: Bhagavad Gita|accessdate=27 December 2011 | work=The Times Of India}}</ref>
====Parliament==== {{Wikinews|Indian Parliament irate as Russia poised to ban Bhagavad Gita|Indian Parliament irate as Russia poised to ban ''Bhagavad Gita''}} On December 19, 2011, [[Bhartruhari Mahtab]], leader of the [[Biju Janata Dal]] party, raised up the issue of the ''Bhagavad Gita'' trial in the Indian Parliament ([[Lok Sabha]]), demanding to know what the Indian government was undertaking to protect "the religious rights of Hindus in Russia".<ref name=BBC /> He also called on the government to "impress [this] upon the Russian authorities through diplomatic channels".<ref name=BBC /> The [[Speaker of Lok Sabha|House Speaker]] [[Meira Kumar]] then turned down requests for speeches on the topic and had to adjourn the session amid protests against the ban of the ''Gita'' sparked by Mahtab's statement,<ref name=BBC>{{cite news|title=India MPs angry as Russia court ponders Hindu book ban|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-india-16251763|accessdate=22 December 2011|newspaper=[[BBC]]|date=19 December 2011}}</ref> as angry members of the Parliament across the party lines strongly condemned the ban, shouting: "We will not tolerate an insult to Lord Krishna!"<ref name=NDTV>{{cite news|title=MPs ask govt to intervene as Russian court considers ban on Gita|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/lok-sabha-storm-as-russian-court-decides-whether-to-ban-bhagavad-gita-159070&cp|date=20 December 2011|accessdate=28 December 2011|newspaper=[[NDTV]]}}</ref><ref name=itimes>{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Parliament-ruckus-over-Bhagvad-Gita%0A-facing-ban-in-Russia/articleshow/11166214.cms |work=The Times Of India |title=Parliament ruckus over ''Bhagavad Gita'' facing ban in Russia |date=19 December 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111220151557/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Parliament-ruckus-over-Bhagvad-Gita-facing-ban-in-Russia/articleshow/11166214.cms |archivedate=20 December 2011 }}</ref><ref name=guardian>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/dec/19/bhagavad-gita-russia-india-siberia|title=Bhagavad Gita trial in Russia closes Indian parliament|date=19 December 2011|accessdate=28 December 2011|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|agency=[[Reuters]]|location=London}}</ref> The issue was simultaneously raised in [[Rajya Sabha|Rajya Sabha (the Upper House)]].<ref name=Hindu-LS>{{cite news|title=Protests in Parliament over Bhagwad Gita controversy|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/article2731504.ece|accessdate=22 December 2011|newspaper=[[The Hindu]]|date=20 December 2011|agency=[[Press Trust of India]]|location=Chennai, India}}</ref> This display of political unity surprised the media and prompted a Rajya Sabha member to call the December 19 parliamentary session "a golden day in our history when all differences were deleted to express solidarity for Gita, the book of India".<ref name=ET-Unity>{{cite news|last=Vijay|first=Tarun|title=Political unity over Gita: A historic day in our times|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/politics/nation/political-unity-over-gita-a-historic-day-in-our-times/articleshow/11179979.cms|accessdate=22 December 2011|date=2 December 2011|work=The Times Of India}}</ref>
On December 20, [[Sushma Swaraj]], leader of the largest opposition party [[Bharatiya Janata Party|BJP]] demanded that the Indian government declare the ''Bhagavad Gita'' a "national book".<ref name=HT-NB>{{cite news|title=Declare Bhagavad Gita as national book, demands BJP|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/NewDelhi/Declare-Bhagavad-Gita-as-national-book-demands-BJP/Article1-784744.aspx|accessdate=22 December 2011|newspaper=Hindustan Times|date=20 December 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111220143222/http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/NewDelhi/Declare-Bhagavad-Gita-as-national-book-demands-BJP/Article1-784744.aspx|archivedate=20 December 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Her move seconded by a BJP member of Rajya Sabha, [[Tarun Vijay]], who asked rhetorically "Can sun be banned, Himalayas be banned ...?"<ref name=HT-NB /> Members across party lines voiced their support.<ref name=HT-NB/> [[Deputy Chairman of the Rajya Sabha]] [[K. Rahman Khan]], member of the [[Indian National Congress]], said "the entire house agrees with this and joins in condemning this".<ref name=HT-NB /><ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2011-12-20/news/30538238_1_bhagavad-gita-ban-tarun-vijay|title=Rajya Sabha condemns Russian move to ban Gita|accessdate=22 December 2011|newspaper=[[The Economic Times]]|date=20 December 2011|author=[[Indo-Asian News Service|IANS]]}}</ref>
On December 21, a Bharatiya Janata Party delegation led by the party's foreign affairs chief [[Vijay Jolly]] met with the Deputy Chief of the Russian Mission in Delhi Denis Alipov to express the party's "pain and anguish" at the ''Bhagavad Gita'' trial and demand that "suitable measures" be taken by the Russian government to immediately dismiss the court case as baseless. Jolly also expressed surprise that the Russian government allowed the trial to continue for over half a year despite the fact that "[[India–Russia relations]] is of paramount importance to both countries". The delegation also sent through the Russian embassy a copy of the ''Bhagavad Gita'' to [[President of Russia]] [[Dmitry Medvedev]] along with a letter, in which the BJP delegation stressed to the Russian President that the Gita is a book of "sublime thoughts" that "preaches self discipline ... promotes spiritualism and teaches to the mankind the need to fulfill responsibility towards worldly duties".<ref name=Outlook-BJP>{{cite news|title=Take Steps to Withdraw Gita Case: BJP to Russia|url=http://news.outlookindia.com/items.aspx?artid=745136|accessdate=22 December 2011|newspaper=[[Outlook (magazine)|Outlook]]|date=21 December 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120616082341/http://news.outlookindia.com/items.aspx?artid=745136|archive-date=16 June 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
====Government==== According to officials of the [[Prime Minister of India]]'s office, "[t]his matter is receiving the highest attention and the Indian embassy officials in Moscow have been instructed to follow up the case with the Russian authorities", in order to either have the case withdrawn by the state or resolved.<ref name=TOI>{{cite news|author= N. C. Bipindra|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/europe/Bhagavad-Gita-faces-extremist-branding-ban-in-Russia/articleshow/11143014.cms|title = Bhagavad Gita faces 'extremist' branding, ban in Russia|date = December 17, 2011|publisher = [[Times of India]]|work = [[Indo-Asian News Service]]|accessdate = December 17, 2011}}</ref> Minister of State for Parliamentary Affairs [[Rajeev Shukla]] said that the Indian authorities are "apprising the Russian government" on the issue.<ref name=Hindu-LS /> However, members of the Parliament accused the Indian government of inaction. They said that on November 1, ISKCON informed [[Prime Minister of India|Prime Minister]] [[Manmohan Singh]]'s principal secretary [[Pulok Chatterji]] of the impending court case, urging the government to use "some high-level ministerial visits" to Moscow, prior to the Prime Minister's own visit December 15–17, to protect the scripture from legal action.<ref name=Hindu-LS /><ref name=HT-NB /> The letter, written by ISKCON's [[Governing Body Commission]]er [[Gopala Krishna Goswami]], cited the assessment as stating that "Krishna is evil and not compatible with Christian views".<ref name=HT-NB /><ref name="TOI"/><ref name=IT-CHR>{{cite news|title=Declare 'Bhagavad Gita' as national book, BJP tells govt|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/bhagavad-gita-row-india-russia/1/165053.html|accessdate=20 March 2012|newspaper=[[India Today]]|agency = [[Indo-Asian News Service]]|date=20 December 2011}}</ref><ref name=AsianAge /> Despite the advance notice, which was also sent to the [[United Progressive Alliance|United Progressive Alliance (UPA)]] chairperson [[Sonia Gandhi]], [[Ministry of Commerce and Industry (India)|Commerce and Industry Minister]] [[Anand Sharma]], and the [[Minister of External Affairs (India)|External Affairs Minister]] [[S. M. Krishna]], the issue was not discussed with the Russian government during the following six official visits of Indian ministers and top officials to Moscow.<ref name=HT-NB /><ref name=AsianAge>{{cite news|title=India had advance notice of 'ban Gita' move in Russia|url=http://www.asianage.com/international/india-had-advance-notice-ban-gita-move-russia-576|accessdate=22 December 2011|newspaper=[[Asian Age]]|date=20 December 2011}}</ref> Officials who were part of the delegation accompanying the Prime Minister confirmed receipt of the letter to the [[Indo-Asian News Service]].<ref name=TOI /><ref name=AsianAge />
====Ministry of External Affairs==== [[Image:India-eam-krishna.jpg|right|thumb|upright|alt=A color photo of the Indian External Affairs Minister S. M. Krishna|Indian [[Minister of External Affairs (India)|Foreign Minister]] [[S. M. Krishna]].]] Following the Parliament's demand for a report from the [[Ministry of External Affairs (India)|External Affairs Ministry]] on the issue, [[Minister of External Affairs (India)|Foreign Minister]] [[S. M. Krishna]] said that ISKCON had been advised to take legal recourse and put the controversy in the light of [[Russia-India relations]].<ref name=STAT-BAN>{{cite news|title=Gita row: India talks to Russian authorities|url=http://www.thestatesman.net/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=394013&catid=36|accessdate=20 December 2011|newspaper=[[The Statesman (India)|The Statesman]]|date=20 December 2011|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130112082332/http://www.thestatesman.net/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=394013&catid=36|archive-date=12 January 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name=DNAx>{{cite news|title=Russian court rejects application seeking ban on Bhagvad Gita|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report_russian-court-rejects-application-seeking-ban-on-bhagvad-gita_1630899|accessdate=28 December 2011|newspaper=[[Daily News and Analysis]]|date=28 December 2011|agency=[[Press Trust of India|PTI]]}}</ref> He also stated in Lok Sabha that "the Bhagavad-gita is the definitive treatise of Indian thought."
====High Court==== On December 21, the [[Bombay High Court|High Court of Mumbai]] questioned the Indian government as to the measures it is undertaking to intervene in the possible ban of the ''Bhagavad Gita'' and directed the government to consider representing the position of India on the issue before the court in Tomsk.<ref name=TOI-HC>{{cite news|last=Sequeira|first=Rosy|title=HC: Centre may represent India in Gita ban case|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-12-22/mumbai/30546508_1_indian-embassy-russian-court-bhagwad-gita|accessdate=22 December 2011|newspaper=[[Times of India]]|date=22 December 2011}}</ref><ref name=IE-HC>{{cite news|title=What steps taken in Gita ban case: HC to govt|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/what-steps-taken-in-gita-ban-case-hc-to-govt/890619/|accessdate=22 December 2011|newspaper=[[Indian Express]]|date=22 December 2011}}</ref> The High Court decision came in response to a [[Public Interest Litigation]] filed by two local activists charging the Indian government with inaction in regard to informing the Russian court of the actual purport of the ''Bhagavad Gita'', and that the Indian Embassy's "monitoring the matter closely" was not sufficient.<ref name=TOI-HC /> The court observed Indian Foreign Minister S. M. Krishna's Parliament statement does not imply if Indian government's direct involvement with the December 28 ''Bhagavad Gita'' trial hearing and asked the government to submit its reply on the steps taken by January 9.<ref name=IE-HC />
====Religious groups==== [[File:Hare Krishnas rallying at Russian Consulate in Kolkata.JPG|thumb|[[ISKCON]] devotees rallying in front of the Russian Consulate in Kolkata (India) demanding to stop the ''[[Bhagavad Gita As It Is]]'' trial. 19 December 2011]] On December 19, dozens of ISKCON followers organized a rally in front of the Russian Consulate in [[Kolkata]], holding up copies of the ''Bhagavad Gita As It Is'' in various languages and demanding to stop persecution of their most important scripture.<ref name=Reuters>{{cite news|last=Prusty|first=Nigam|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/12/19/uk-india-russia-idUKTRE7BI0W620111219|title=Hold India uproar at call in Russia to ban Hindu holy book|work=[[Reuters]]|date=December 19, 2011|accessdate=December 20, 2011}}</ref> Similar protest marches were held in [[New Delhi]]<ref name=HT-GKG>{{cite news|last=Arora|first=Rajat|title=ISKCON: If Gita is banned, we’ll intensify protest|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/NewDelhi/Iskcon-If-Gita-is-banned-we-ll-intensify-protest/Article1-785039.aspx|accessdate=18 February 2012|newspaper=[[Hindustan Times]]|date=20 December 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111221010708/http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/NewDelhi/Iskcon-If-Gita-is-banned-we-ll-intensify-protest/Article1-785039.aspx|archive-date=21 December 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and [[Chandigarh]].<ref name=TOI-On>{{cite news|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-12-20/chandigarh/30537527_1_bhagawad-gita-signatures-petition|title=Bhagawad Gita on trial gathers online support|last=Negi|first=Himanshi|date=December 20, 2011|work=[[Times of India]]|accessdate=December 20, 2011}}</ref> [[Gopal Krishna Goswami]], ISKCON's [[Governing Body Commission]]er for India, said that ISKCON members are poised to intensify their public protests across the globe if their scripture is banned. He said, "I hope the Indian government will be able to pressurize the Russian government and the matter gets solved legally. It's a book of peace and there's nothing extreme in it. Holy scriptures shouldn't be taken to court".<ref name=HT-GKG />
On December 21, a highly respected Islamic seminary [[Darul Uloom Deoband]] issued a statement signed by its vice-chancellor Abul Qasim Nomani in defense of the ''Bhagavad Gita'', in which he condemned "Russian diktat against the Hindu holy scripture".<ref name=TOI-ISL>{{cite news|last=Mishra|first=Manjari|title=Darul Uloom Deoband urges Hindus, Muslims to unite on Gita|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-12-22/india/30546086_1_darul-uloom-deoband-hindus-muslims|accessdate=22 December 2011|newspaper=[[Times of India]]|date=22 December 2011}}</ref> Nomani also called accusations of the Gita of extremism "totally baseless and highly objectionable",<ref name=TOI-ISL /> maintaining that the proposed ban is tantamount to violation of the freedom of conscience "enshrined" in the Indian Constitution, and called on boldly countering the "Russian highhandedness".<ref name=TOI-ISL /> Maulana Khalid Rashid, head of [[Firangi Mahal]], another Islamic center of higher education in [[Lucknow]], also condemned what he called "Russian arrogance" and called on Muslims to support Hindu followers while appealing to the Indian government "to take a firm stance so that such blasphemous interference is not attempted in future".<ref name=TOI-ISL />
On December 22, 2011, [[Isai Mahasangh]] organization representing Christians in the Indian state of [[Madhya Pradesh]] addressed the [[President of India]] [[Pratibha Patil]] and the [[Pope Benedict XVI]], asking for their intervention in the ''Bhagavad Gita'' trial. An Isai Mahasangh delegation conveyed their memorandum to the President through Madhya Pradesh governor [[Ram Naresh Yadav]], and to the Pope through the [[Holy See]] embassy in [[New Delhi]]. Jerry Paul, General Secretary of Isai Mahasangh, stated that it was clear from the court case against the Gita that "the Russians are not aware of the importance of the Gita, the teachings and values it upholds and above all its place in the life of millions of Indians".<ref name=Hindu-Chr>{{cite news|last=Singh|first=Mahim Pratap|title=Christians in MP oppose proposed Russian ban on Gita|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/states/other-states/article2738302.ece|accessdate=22 December 2011|newspaper=[[The Hindu]]|date=22 December 2011|location=Chennai, India}}</ref>
A prominent Hindu teacher [[Sri Sri Ravi Shankar]] in his Twitter called the proposed ban of the ''Bhagavad Gita'' in Russia "an unpardonable loss for the people of Russia" and, countering accusations of the book of "extremism" and "intolerance" opined that it was the move to ban the scripture that showed intolerance and bred terrorism rather than the Gita's teachings.<ref name=DB-NET>{{cite news|title=Bhagavad Gita ban: Outrage grows as sales soar|url=http://daily.bhaskar.com/article/NAT-TOP-bhagvad-gita-ban-outrage-grows-as-sales-soar-2660886.html?HT4=|accessdate=22 December 2011|newspaper=[[Dainik Bhaskar|Daily Bhaskar]]|date=21 December 2011|agency=with [[Press Trust of India|PTI]] input}}</ref>
====Hindu activists==== On December 20, 2011, the [[Vishwa Hindu Parishad|Vishwa Hindu Parishad (VHP)]] threatened to protest outside Russian missions in India if Russia effects the ban. VHP General Secretary [[Pravin Togadia]] said in a statement that the ''Bhagavad Gita'' is held sacred by all Hindus and that its principles have universal appeal and "touch humanity so very deeply", citing [[Albert Einstein]]'s fascination with the book as an example. Togadia also warned Russian authorities that Indians will be forced to boycott Russian goods, plants, and offices in India in response to the Gita ban in Russia.<ref name=AA-VHP>{{cite news|title=VHP threatens Russian establishments with retaliation if Gita is banned|url=http://www.asianage.com/india/vhp-threatens-russian-establishments-retaliation-if-gita-banned-632|accessdate=22 December 2011|newspaper=[[Asian Age]]|date=20 December 2011}}</ref> A group of VHP members held a protest march in front of the [[Russian consulate in Mumbai]].<ref name=NYT>{{cite news|last=Kates|first=Glenn|title=In Russia, the Bhagavad Gita has a date in court|url=http://india.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/12/23/in-russia-the-bhagavad-gita-has-a-date-in-court/|accessdate=23 December 2011|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=23 December 2011}}</ref> VHP and [[Bajrang Dal]] activists also staged protest in [[Chandigarh]], calling on the Indian government to protect the rights of [[Hindus in Russia]] and denouncing the proposed ban.<ref name=DB-VHP>{{cite news|title=VHP, Bajrang Dal protest against bid to ban Bhagwad Gita|url=http://daily.bhaskar.com/article/PUN-NEWS-vhp-bajrang-dal-protest-against-bid-to-ban-bhagwad-gita-2657671.html?LHS-|accessdate=22 December 2011|newspaper=[[Dainik Bhaskar|Daily Bhaskar]]|date=21 December 2011|agency=with [[Press Trust of India|PTI]] input}}</ref> On December 23, dozens of activists of [[Rashtrawadi Sena]], a hardline Hindu group, burned a [[Flag of Russia|Russian flag]] and shouted anti-Russian slogans during a protest march in [[New Delhi]] over the proposed ban. Rashtrawadi Sena president Jai Bhagwan Goyal called the ''Gita'' "the most pious book of the nation" and said there will be no tolerance for insulting it. The protesters also sent a memorandum to Indian President Pratibha Patil, and to the Russian embassy, demanding to avert the ban. They also urged the President to declare the ''Bhagavad Gita'' a "national scripture" in order to prevent such insults in the future.<ref name=RT>{{cite news|title=Religion or extremism? Russian court to decide fate of Hindu holy book|url=http://rt.com/news/hindu-book-extremism-trial-763/|accessdate=28 December 2011|newspaper=[[RT (TV network)]]|date=27 December 2011}}</ref><ref name=RSena>{{cite news|title=Hindu hardline group protests against Bhagavad Gita ban|url=http://www.newstrackindia.com/newsdetails/256185|accessdate=28 December 2011|newspaper=News Track India|date=23 December 2011|agency=[[Asian News International|ANI]]}}</ref> A similar protest along with the burning of a Russian flag was held on December 26 by activists of the right-wing Hindu organisation [[Shiv Sena]] in [[Amritsar]].<ref name=RT /> In a similar move, a [[Jammu]] unit of [[Sri Ram Sena]] appealed to Indian and Russian authorities to forestall the impending ''Gita '' ban "for the betterment of Indo-Russia relations".<ref name=IBN-Sena>{{cite news|title=Ram Sena urges Russian officials to amicably solve Gita issue|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/generalnewsfeed/news/ram-sena-urges-russian-officials-to-amicably-solve-gita-issue/941752.html|accessdate=28 December 2011|newspaper=[[CNN-IBN|IBN Live]]|agency=[[Press Trust of India|PTI]]|date=23 December 2011}}</ref>
====Atheists and rationalists==== [[Sanal Edamaruku]], the president of the [[Indian Rationalist Association]], opposed the ban calling for the right to read any literature under the freedom of expression, even if he considered the book to be promoting the caste system. Similarly, Dr Jayagopal, the founder of the Atheist Society of India, opposed the ban, in spite of considering the book to be undemocratic and against the spirit of the constitution. He also suspected that the [[Russian Orthodox Church]] may have been behind the ban. Megh Raj Mitter, the founder of the [[Tarksheel Society]], also opposed this move, but admitted that Russians may have been offended by the book and their sentiments should be respected.<ref name=atheist/>
On the other hand, [[Dalit]] [[Marxist]] scholar Chittibabu Padavala supported the ban, as he considered Gita to be promoting inequalities from the birth unlike other religious texts.<ref name=atheist>{{cite news|title=Atheists, rationalists oppose ban on Bhagwat Gita|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2011-12-23/news/30550973_1_ban-iskon-bhagwat-gita|publisher=The Economic Times|accessdate=5 September 2013|date=23 December 2011}}</ref>
====Russian community in Goa====
On December 21, 2011, the Russian community in [[Goa]] has issued a statement condemning the proposed ban on the ''Bhagavad Gita'' in Russia. Speaking on behalf of the 150-strong community, Russian consulate in Goa [[Vikram Varma]] stated: "The Russian community in Goa as a whole condemns the possibility of a ban on any of India's ancient scriptures. It is felt by the Russian community in Goa as well as by a large section of Russians visiting Goa that the depth of knowledge and wisdom offered by the Bhagavad Gita cannot be understood by a casual reader. It is well accepted that all the ancient Hindu scriptures are of tremendous importance not only to India but to the rest of the world."<ref>{{cite news|title=Russians in Goa flay possibility of ban on Gita|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-12-22/goa/30545829_1_russian-consulate-russian-city-goa|accessdate=22 December 2011|newspaper=[[Times of India]]|date=22 December 2011|agency=[[Times News Network]]}}</ref>
====Society==== The trial sparked community protests in India. On December 16, 2011, an online petition to stop the ''Bhagavad Gita'' trial was launched, and by December 22 more than 45,000 people from all over the world, mostly from India.<ref name=TOI-On />
The topic has gone viral on social networks, with the [[hashtag]] #Gita becoming a leading trend on Indian [[Twitter]].<ref name=Reuters /><ref name=TOI-On /><ref name=DB-NET /> Noted poet and lyricist [[Javed Akhtar]], for instance, twitted: "Banning Gita ? Have they lost their minds. This great book of wisdom belongs not only to Hindus but to the whole humanity".<ref name=DB-NET /><ref name=Link>{{cite news|title=Should Bhagavad Gita be India’s National Book?|url=http://thelinkpaper.ca/?p=12828|accessdate=28 December 2011|newspaper=The Link|date=24 December 2011}}</ref> Member of Parilament [[Naveen Jindal]] wrote in his blog, "I welcome the statement by the Russian ambassador to India condemning the ''Bhagavad Gita'' controversy".<ref name=DB-NET /> [[Janata Dal]] party leader [[Subramanian Swamy]] wrote on Twitter: "Happy to inform that Russian Ambassador will tell my daughter on TV that he is a student of Gita and Russia will rectify matters soon. Ok?"<ref name=DB-NET /> and Bollywood celebrity [[Farah Khan]] suggested in a retweet: "The Russians have banned the Gita. In retaliation let's ban something equally sacrosanct to them: vodka".<ref name=DB-NET />
Prominent social activists from a broad societal spectrum also condemned the trial.<ref name=Rediff-3>{{cite news|last=Nanjappa|first=Vicky|title=Bhagavad Gita ban:Three views, three solutions|url=http://www.rediff.com/news/slide-show/slide-show-1-debate-bhagavad-gita-ban/20111223.htm|accessdate=23 December 2011|newspaper=Rediff News|date=23 December 2011}}</ref> A vocal anti-fundamentalist [[Ram Puniyani]] of the EKTA Committee for Communal Amity called the move to ban the ''Bhagavad Gita'' translation "irrational",<ref name=Rediff-3 /> suggesting that possible questionable passages should be analyzed and debated, but they do not warrant the legal action.<ref name=Rediff-3 /> Former president of the [[Students Islamic Movement of India]] Shahid Badr Falahi said he was "completely against"<ref name=Rediff-3 /> this or any other bans of religious books, calling on "equal opinion on issues pertaining to every religion".<ref name=Rediff-3 /> [[Ram Madhav]], national executive member of the [[Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh]] termed the attempted ban "a shameful act" planned by some "fundamentalist groups in Russia" to portray the Bhagavad Gita as a "terror manual".<ref name=Rediff-3 /> He emphasized the Gita's status as one of the most sacred texts respected in all religions and expressed hope that the Russian government will help stop the trial.<ref name=Rediff-3 />
===In Russia=== The Russian society appears to be embarrassed by the court case over the Gita, with the media mostly condemning the ongoing trial, carrying reports titled like "Trial of Indian book brings shame to Tomsk". A prominent Russian Internet paper Gazeta.ru published a satirical article on how a work that was created 5,000 years ago has suddenly become an extremist document.<ref name=TOI-MAU />
====Indian diaspora and ISKCON==== Hare Krishna followers, who count over 100,000 members and over 100 centers in Russia, expressed fear that the trial on their main scripture, if upheld by the court, will be followed by a ban of their entire movement and religion nationwide.<ref name=MoscowTimes /><ref name=HT-NB /><ref name=TOI /> The 15,000-strong Hindu community in Russia shared the apprehension.<ref name=HT-NB /> On November 1, ISKCON leader in India [[Gopal Krishna Goswami]] appealed to the Indian government asking to intervene and resolve the impending trial by bringing it up with the Russian authorities during Indian official visits to Moscow.<ref name=HT-NB /> Hindu followers in Russia from India, [[Bangladesh]], [[Mauritius]], [[Nepal]] and other countries held an emergency meeting, at which they set up the [[Hindu Council of Russia]] meant to protect their interests in Russia, and elected [[Sadhu Priya Das]], and India-born member of ISKCON, as its chairman. Das said that they were seeking opinion of the Russian Ombudsman and experts from Moscow and St. Petersburg, the main centers of Indology in Russia,<ref name=TOI-MAU /> and that they trusted the Russian judiciary, hoping that "finally the truth will prevail".<ref name=STAT-BAN /><ref name=Statesman />
ISKCON members alleged that the court case was instigated by the Russian Orthodox Church in order to limit their activities in Russia.<ref name=NYT /><ref name=AP /><ref name=HTx/><ref name=IBNLx /><ref name=Reuters /><ref name=RIR-reject>{{cite news|title=Tomsk court rejects bid to ban "Bhagavad-Gita"|url=http://indrus.in/articles/2011/12/28/tomsk_court_rejects_the_bid_to_ban_bhagavad-gita_14108.html|newspaper=Russia & India Report|date=December 28, 2011}}</ref><ref name=RIR-bilateral>{{cite news|title=Bhagavad Gita in court: Overcoming unexpected roadblock to relationship|url=http://indrus.in/articles/2012/01/10/bhagavad_gita_in_court_overcoming_unexpected_roadblock_to_bilateral_14141.html|newspaper=Russia & India Report|date=January 10, 2012}}</ref>
====Scholars==== [[Islamic studies]] scholar [[Roman Silantyev]] opined that Prabhupada's interpretation "has nothing to do with traditional Hinduism" and that his commentaries contained statements that can be considered extremist.<ref name=Interfax-MID>{{cite news|title=Tomsk trial held over "Bhagavad Gita" translation, not book proper – ministry|url=http://www.interfax-religion.com/?act=news&div=8941|accessdate=23 December 2011|date=23 December 2011|agency=[[Interfax]]}}</ref>
On November 28, at a round table organized by Russian newspaper ''[[Moskovskij Komsomolets]]'', scientists and members of the [[Russian Academy of Sciences]] along with a few religious leaders stated in a resolution, "there is no basis for conducting such a trial and the very fact of initiating a trial by the public prosecutor is an insult to the religious feelings of followers of Vaishnavism in India and Russia and it will give a body blow to Indo-Russian relations."<ref name=TOI-MAU />
Sergey Serebryanny, the head of the [[Institute of High Humanitarian Studies]] at the [[Russian State University for the Humanities]] and an Indologist, said Russian courts give the term ‘extremism’ a very broad interpretation, which allows them to label as extremist anything going against the authorities, whether secular or religious. He also opined that, while Prabhupada supplemented his version of the ''Bhagavad Gita'' with his own ideas and beliefs, his followers "have the same right for the freedom of conscience as believers of other religious confessions that observe the laws of the Russian Federation".<ref name=RT />
Russian Indologist Yevgenia Vanina of the [[Institute of Oriental Studies of the Russian Academy of Sciences]] wrote an article severely criticizing the court case over the ''Bhagavad Gita'', which "is revered by millions in India, Nepal, Sri Lanka and wherever Hindus live". She reminded that in Europe, the Gita was "admired by many great philosophers and thinkers, such as Herder, Schopenhauer and Tolstoy" and thought it ironic that while the Hindu scripture was first translated into Russian in 1788, "nobody put the book and its translators on trial in the Orthodox Russian Empire in 1788, but it’s being judged in secular democratic Russia". Vanina also argued that charges of extremism against Prabhupada's "copious" commentaries on the ''Bhagavad Gita'' are fallacious and based on a "primitive" screening of the religious text for negative words (such as "fool," "enemy," "demon, "kill"). According to Vanina, using this approach, any ancient text, from the Greek myths to the Bible, and the Koran, can be found extremism, especially when "specialists in philosophical suicidology are entrusted with passing judgement on ancient Indian texts". Vanina concluded by opining that, despite people's right to their attitudes towards "a Russian lad wearing Indian clothes and singing Hare Krishna", ISKCON followers have the right to practice their religion, and that the Russian Orthodox Church, instead of calling for a ban on competitors or attempting to legally equate their holy book to ''Mein Kampf'', should introspect as to the reasons that deter young Russians from joining the Church. Otherwise, Vanina predicted, "people will again start being burned alive".<ref name=RIR-Vanina />
Historian and full professor of the Diplomatic Academy at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Russia Andrey Volodin opined that the move to ban the ''Gita'' was "contrary to the basic principle of tolerance inherent in Russian civilisation". He said that this trial, held in Tomsk, "one of Russia’s intellectual capitals, raises doubts as to whether the local leaders are sane and the intellectual community in one of the country’s main academic and university centers is actually mature". To a question, which forces in Russia are interested in a ban on the ''Bhagavad Gita'' Volodin replied that "all the intelligence services in the world, including the CIA and M16, could never have come up with a more effective move to compromise Russia in India and in the world".<ref name=RIR-Volodin>{{cite news|last=Volodin|first=Andrei|title=Gita row: A test of Russian toleration|url=http://indrus.in/articles/2011/12/23/gita_row_a_test_of_russian_toleration_14077.html|accessdate=23 December 2011|newspaper=Russia & India Report|date=23 December 2011}}</ref>
====Government==== In an interview by ''[[CNN-IBN]]'', Russia's ambassador to India [[Alexander Kadakin]] called ''Bhagavad Gita'' "the source of wisdom and inspiration not only for the people of India but for Russia as well and the world." <ref name=KadCNN>{{cite news|url=http://m.ibnlive.com/news/bhagvad-gita-a-sacred-text-in-russia-as-well/3/213652.html|title=Bhagvad Gita a sacred text in Russia as well|last = Haidar|first=Suhasini|work=[[CNN-IBN]]|date=December 20, 2011|accessdate=December 22, 2011}}</ref> <ref name=KadWSJ>{{cite news|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/indiarealtime/2011/12/20/bhagavad-gita-extremist-label-riles-lawmakers/?mod=google_news_blog|title=Bhagavad Gita ‘Extremist’ Label Riles Lawmakers|work=[[Wall Street Journal]]|date=20 December 2011|last=Rana|first=Preeetika|accessdate=22 December 2011}}</ref> <ref name=KadTOI>{{cite news|title=Taking scripture to court inadmissible: Russian ambassador|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-12-21/india/30542175_1_court-in-tomsk-city-extremist-text-secular-credentials|accessdate=22 December 2011|newspaper=[[Times of India]]|date=21 December 2011|author=TNN}}</ref> and commended the Indian Parliament and government for their resolute stance on the Bhagavad Gita trial in Russia, opining that both countries nations, being secular, democratic, and multi-cofessional, "should not allow such things to happen".<ref name=KadCNN /> He assured that the Russian government is using all means to end the ''Bhagavad Gita'' scandal and added that he thought it "categorically inadmissible" to take any sacred scriptures "for examination to ignorant people" to the courts rather than to academic forums<ref name=IE-RU>{{cite news|title=Russia expresses sadness over Bhagwad Gita controversy|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/russia-expresses-sadness-over-bhagwad-gita-controversy/889960/0|accessdate=22 December 2011|newspaper=[[Indian Express]]|date=20 December 2011}}</ref><ref name=KadCNN /><ref name=KadTOI /> Kadakin ruled out the possibility of the Russian government directly influencing the court decision, but added that the government still "can do something" and called the instigators of the trial "madmen", whose "madness should be stopped."<ref name=KadCNN /> He also answered a question of a possible apology to the people of India by the Russian government, opining that since it was not the Russian government who started the case, it "has nothing to apologize for, [but] can only testify and reiterate the love and affection and highest esteem our nation has for Bhagvat Gita."<ref name=KadCNN />
On December 27, 2011, after a meeting with the Foreign Minister of India S. M. Krishna, at which Krishna reiterated India's grave concerns over the issue, Kadakin told reporters that the Russian government will do everything within its powers to prevent the ban.<ref name=TOI-SMK>{{cite news|title=Krishna discusses Bhagavad Gita row with Russian ambassador|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-12-27/india/30560871_1_court-in-tomsk-city-bhagavad-gita-nerpa|accessdate=27 December 2011|newspaper=Times of India|date=27 December 2011|agency=[[Press Trust of India|PTI]]}}</ref> He said that, while it was a judicial process, the Russian government can ask the people of Russia "to express our love and admiration for the Gita, ... that [assurance] you can get from anyone in Russia". He also added that he had read the Gita and thought it was a great scripture of the world, and maintained that "no holy scripture, whether it is Bible, Quran or Gita, can be brought to a court".<ref name=TOI-SMK />
According to the Minister of State for Parliamentary Affairs Rajeev Shukla, a top Russian minister also "expressed regrets" about the situation.<ref name=Hindu-LS />
Russian [[Ombudsman|Chief Director]] for [[Human rights in Russia|Human Rights]] [[Vladimir Lukin]] stated that the attempt to ban ''Bhagavad Gita As It Is'' amounted to "infringement on the constitutional right to the freedom of consciousness"<ref name=TheHindu>{{cite news|last=Radyushin|first=Vladimir|title=India asks Russia to drop the case against Gita translation|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/international/article2731900.ece|accessdate=22 December 2011|newspaper=The Hindu|date=20 December 2011|location=Chennai, India}}</ref> and that it was "unacceptable" to ban the ''Bhagavad Gita As It Is'' written by ISKCON founder Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupada, in Russia, as he said it was a "globally respected book".<ref name=Statesman>{{cite news|title=Gita ban: Russian court suspends verdict till 28 Dec|url=http://www.thestatesman.net/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=393903&catid=36|accessdate=22 December 2011|date=19 December 2011|newspaper=[[The Statesman (India)|The Statesman]]|agency=[[Press Trust of India]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120108011714/http://www.thestatesman.net/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=393903&catid=36|archivedate=8 January 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> As the Ombudsman for Russia, Vladimir Lukun took the Bhagavad Gita court case under his special control<ref name=KadCNN /> and will testify in the court on December 28 asking to dismiss the charges.<ref name=TheHindu-MID>{{cite news|last=Radyushin|first=Vladimir|title=Gita ban: Russia rejects India's complaints|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/international/article2741599.ece?homepage=true|accessdate=23 December 2011|newspaper=[[The Hindu]]|date=23 December 2011|location=Chennai, India}}</ref>
At a December 22, 2011 press briefing, [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Russia)|Russian Foreign Ministry]] spokesman Alexander Lukashevich attempted to clarify a number of points seemingly misunderstood by his Indian colleagues: "In June this year Tomsk prosecutors instigated legal proceedings against the third edition of the Russian translation of 'Bhagavad Gita As It Is' with a view to have it added to the federal list of extremist materials. I would like to stress that the trial is not about 'Bhagavad Gita', a religious philosophical poem, which forms part of the great Indian epic Mahabharata and is one of the most famous texts of the ancient Hindu literature. In Russia, the book was first published in Russian in 1788 and then went through many editions in different years and in various translations. The Tomsk court case is about classifying as extremist material the Russian-language edition of 'Bhagavad Gita As It Is', written in 1968 by A. C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupada, founder of the International Society for Krishna Consciousness. The work represents an authorized translation of the original from Sanskrit into English. The book was translated into Russian in 1984. As evident from the materials available, the complaints of law enforcement are not so much about the text of the book itself, whose double translation suffers from semantic distortions, as about the author's comments which were regarded as falling under Article 13 of the Federal Law 'On Counteracting Extremist Activity'."<ref name=Interfax-MID /><ref name=RIR-Interfax>{{cite news|author=Interfax|title=Tomsk trial held over "Bhagavad Gita" translation, not book proper - ministry|url=http://indrus.in/articles/2011/12/23/tomsk_trial_held_over_bhagavad_gita_translation_not_book_proper_-_mi_14078.html|newspaper=Russia & India Report|date=23 December 2011}}</ref><ref name=TheHindu-MID /><ref name=MID-brief>{{cite press release |script-title=ru:Брифинг официального представителя МИД России А.К.Лукашевича, 22 декабря 2011 года|trans-title=Briefing by the spokesman of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Russia, Mr. Lukashevitch, December 22, 2011|publisher=[[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Russia)|Foreign Ministry]]|date=22 December 2011|url=http://www.mid.ru/brp_4.nsf/briefview/5A299EC9BE98767A4425796E005447BD|language=Russian}}</ref>
Nelly Krechetova, Human Rights Ombudsman of Tomsk region, has termed the trial "absurd". Speaking on the ''[[Echo of Moscow]]'' radio station, she said, "This book is considered sacred by more than a billion people the world over, and in Russia itself the book has been in circulation for 20 years." She continued that there was no manifest incident of extremism caused by the dissemination of the book. A ban on the book, she said, would amount to "violation of constitutional rights of citizens to freedom of conscience and faith." <ref name=TOI-MAU />
===International=== ''[[Associated Press]]'' reported that the attempt to ban ''Bhagavad Gita As It Is'' angered Hindus around the world.<ref name=AP> *{{cite news |title=Russian court to consider ban on key text of Hare Krishna movement |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/russian-court-to-consider-ban-on-key-text-of-hare-krishna-movement/2011/12/28/gIQA1GUgLP_story.html |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/64JDsoJUk?url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/russian-court-to-consider-ban-on-key-text-of-hare-krishna-movement/2011/12/28/gIQA1GUgLP_story.html |archivedate=30 December 2011 |accessdate=29 December 2011 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=28 December 2011 |agency=[[Associated Press]] |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} *{{cite news |last=Javed |first=Sofia |url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/russian-court-ban-hare-krishna-text-15243747#.Tvr96BNOhzH |title=Russian court may ban Hare Krishna text |accessdate=28 December 2011 |newspaper=[[ABC News]] |date=28 December 2011 |agency=[[Associated Press]] }}</ref>
The court case evoked protests by US-based [[Hindu]] activists, who called the trial "an attack on religious freedom and belittling of the entire [[Hindu]] community."<ref name=YahooNews>{{cite news|url=http://in.news.yahoo.com/hindus-upset-bhagavad-gita-ban-attempt-russian-city-095924009.html|title=Hindus upset at Bhagavad Gita ban attempt by Russian city|work= [[Asian News International|ANI]]|publisher = [[Yahoo! News]]|date=November 29, 2011|accessdate=December 19, 2011}}</ref> The [[Hindu American Foundation]] (HAF) based in [[Washington, DC]] expressed "shock and outrage" over the attempted ban. Subhag Shukla, HAF managing director, called the move by Russian prosecutors "indefensible" and "a draconian attempt to restrict the religious freedom of Hindus in Russia". Shukla added that, "[b]y promoting a narrow and intolerant agenda that demonizes a sacred scripture revered by more than one billion Hindus worldwide, Russian officials are acting contrary to the principles of a free democratic society".<ref name=HAF /> HAF members conveyed their concerns in an official statement to the Russian embassy in Washington, DC, requesting a follow-up meeting to monitor the situation, and urged the Russian judiciary and government "to uphold the basic rights of their Hindu citizens". They also warned that "Any court ruling or law that would prohibit the Bhagavad Gita or any other Hindu religious literature would be considered a direct attack on the civil liberties of Russia's Hindu community and an affront to Hindus throughout the world".<ref name=HAF>{{cite news|last=Jha|first=Lalit K.|title=Hindus in US outraged at attempts to ban Gita in Russia|url=http://news.in.msn.com/international/article.aspx?cp-documentid=5694646|accessdate=27 December 2011|newspaper=[[MSN News]]|agency=[[Press Trust of India|PTI]]|date=21 December 2011}}</ref>
In [[Kathmandu]], Nepal, a consortium of the country's Hindu organizations, [[Rastriya Dharma Sabha Nepal]], condemned the proposed ban, urging the [[Politics of Nepal|government]] and the [[Nepalese Constituent Assembly|Parliament]] to support the ''Bhagavad Gita''. Chairman of the Dharma Sabha [[Madhav Bhattarai]] also requested the Parliament to discuss the issue and address it with the Russian government and embassy in Nepal.<ref name=HimTimes1>{{cite news|title=Dharma Sabha Nepal denounces ban on Gita|url=http://www.thehimalayantimes.com/fullNews.php?headline=Dharma+Sabha+Nepal+denounces+ban+on+Gita&NewsID=313585|accessdate=26 December 2011|newspaper=[[The Himalayan Times]]|date=22 December 2011}}</ref> Another protest was expressed by a Nepali Shreemadbhagawat Publicity Service Association (SPSA), which emphasized that rather than being extremist, the ''Gita'' "guides one for the self-discipline and responsibility to human duties" and informed of plans to hold rallies against the potential ban.<ref name=HimTimes2>{{cite news|title='Bhagwat Gita is not extremist literature'|url=http://www.thehimalayantimes.com/fullNews.php?headline='Bhagwat+Gita+is+not+extremist+literature'&NewsID=313597&a=3|accessdate=26 December 2011|newspaper=[[The Himalayan Times]]|date=22 December 2011}}</ref>
The [[United States Department of State]] in its annual [[International Religious Freedom Report]] for 2011 cited the Bhagavad Gita trial among instances of "selectively enforced existing legal restrictions on religious freedom" by the Russian government. The report quoted the Russian Ombudsperson for Human Rights Vladimil Lukin as saying that "the struggle with terrorism is a struggle with real terrorist planning and creation of groups, not with the interpretation of ancient holy books, of whatever faith".<ref name=US-DS>{{cite web|last=[[United States Department of State]]|title=International Religious Freedom Report for 2011|url=https://www.state.gov/documents/organization/193067.pdf|publisher=[[Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights and Labor]]|accessdate=1 August 2012}}</ref>
==Reaction to the appeal==
===Scholars=== {{Wikinews|Russian scholars call on Medvedev and Putin to defend Bhagavad Gita}} On February 24, 2012, Russian religious scholars and experts held a nationwide conference ''Bhagavad Gita in history and modern society'' at the Tomsk State University.<ref name=RAPSI-Conf>{{cite news|title=Bhagavad Gita case perplex scientists|url=http://rapsinews.com/judicial_news/20120224/260445972.html|accessdate=25 February 2012|date=24 February 2012|agency=RAPSI}}</ref> They said they were "perplexed" over the Tomsk prosecutor's office's continued attempts to have the ''Bhagavad Gita as It Is'' declared extremist. [[Chief researcher]] of the [[Institute of Oriental Studies of the Russian Academy of Sciences|Institute of Oriental Studies]] of the [[Russian Academy of Sciences]], indologist [[Irina Glushkova]] said in an interview with ''[[RIA Novosti]]'' that there are various schools of Hinduism "and each school is based on its own scripture or commentary", adding that "from this point of view ''Bhagavad Gita As It Is'' has the right to exist as any other commentary or scripture. It is a fundamental principle of Hinduism and there is no any other Hinduism whoever says it, Dvorkin or the Tomsk prosecutor's office".<ref name=RAPSI-Conf /> She also stated it was "impermissible" to subject the ''Bhagavad Gita As It Is'' to a criminal court trial, because "it is inseparable from the original ''Bhagavad Gita'', both being parts of the same culture".<ref>{{cite news|script-title=ru:Рассматривать "Бхагавад-гиту как она есть" с точки зрения Уголовного кодекса - недопустимо, утверждают ученые|trans-title=Scholars: It's impermissible to view the Bhagavad Gita As It Is via the Criminal Code|url=http://www.interfax-russia.ru/Siberia/report.asp?id=295556|accessdate=25 February 2012|date=24 February 2012|agency=[[Interfax]]|language=Russian}}</ref> Philosopher [[Tatyana Lyubimova]], chief researcher of the [[Institute of Philosophy of the Russian Academy of Sciences]], said that most ancient scriptures, including the ''Bhagavad Gita'', were revised or adapted over the years so that modern people could better understand them.<ref name=RAPSI-Conf />
On March 12, 2012, a group of twenty leading Russian [[philosophy|philosophers]], [[Oriental studies|orientologists]], and [[philology|philologists]] published an open letter addressing both [[President of the Russian Federation|Russian President]] [[Dmitry Medvedev]] and the [[Prime Minister of Russia|Russian Prime Minister]] and [[President-elect]] [[Vladimir Putin]], with copies sent to Russia's [[Prosecutor General of Russia|Presecutor General]], [[Ministry of Justice of Russia|Ministry of Justice]], and [[Public Chamber]], urging the ruling tandem to take the ''Bhagavad Gita As It Is'' court case under their "personal control".<ref name=Hindu-20>{{cite news|last=Radyushin|first=Vladimir|title=Russian scholars' plea on Gita|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/international/article2999643.ece|accessdate=16 March 2012|newspaper=[[The Hindu]]|date=15 March 2012|location=Chennai, India}}</ref><ref name=Newsru-20>{{cite news|script-title=ru:Российские ученые просят Медведева и Путина взять процесс над "Бхагавад-гитой" под личный контроль|trans-title=Russian scholars ask Medvedev and Putin to take "Bhagavad Gita" court case under their personal control|url=http://newsru.com/religy/15mar2012/bhagavad.html|accessdate=16 March 2012|newspaper=[[NEWSru]]|date=15 March 2012|language=Russian}}</ref> The scholars said they were alarmed by the Tomsk prosecutor's attempting to overrule the earlier court's rejection of the extremest charges against the book, and filing a modified petition asking the court to ban only Bhaktivedanta Swami's commentaries and exempting the original text from the charges of extremism. The scholars criticized the prosecutor's indictment of the commentaries with extremism as "untrue and contrary to the traditions of Hinduism".<ref name=Hindu-20 /> They emphasized that, contrary to the prosecutor's accusations, the ''Bhagavad Gita As It Is'' was considered sacred by a section of Hindu followers as belonging to the commentary tradition of [[Gaudiya Vaishnavism|Bengali Vaishnavism]], "one of the most popular branches of Hinduism",<ref name=Hindu-20 /> and "did not contain any signs of extremism and did not incite hatred on ethnic, religious or any other grounds".<ref name=Hindu-20 /> The scholars also warned Russia's top leaders that the trial "discredits Russia's cultural and democratic credentials in the eyes of the civilized world and is driving a wedge in Russian-Indian relations".<ref name=Hindu-20 />
===ISKCON=== Maxim Osipov, a representative of ISKCON's [[Governing Body Commission]], said that the commentary to ''Bhagavad Gita As It Is'' is "a precise and clear reflection" on the religious tradition taught by Prabhupada, the founder-[[acharya]] of the International Society for Krishna Consciousness.<ref name=RAPSI-Conf />
==Reaction to the court decision==
===In India=== {{Expand section|date=March 2012}}
"I welcome the verdict of the Honourable District Court in Tomsk today, which has dismissed the appeal petition in the ''Bhagavad Gita'' case. It is good that the decision of the lower trial court in this matter has been reaffirmed. I trust that this issue is now conclusively behind us", said [[Ajai Malhotra]], Indian Ambassador to the Russian Federation.<ref name=RIR-Mar21>{{cite news|title=Tomsk court dismisses Bhagavad Gita case|url=http://indrus.in/articles/2012/03/21/tomsk_court_dismisses_bhagavad_gita_case_15204.html|date=21 March 2012}}</ref>
"We appreciate this sensible resolution of a sensitive issue and are glad to put this episode behind us. We also appreciate the efforts of all friends in Russia who made this outcome possible. This demonstrates yet again that the people of India and Russia have a deep understanding of each other’s cultures and will always reject any attempt to belittle our common civilizational values", said Indian foreign ministry spokesman Vishnu Prakash.<ref name=AP /><ref name=HTx />
===In Russia=== {{expand section|date=April 2012}}
====Human Rights Commissioner==== {{expand section|date=April 2012}} On April 11, 2012 [[Vladimir Lukin]], the [[Human Rights]] [[Commissioner]] of Russia, "warned against court decisions on ''Bhagavad Gita'' texts based on judges' opinions rather than expert examinations." Lukin stated that the "Tomsk [judges] considered something they should not have… It should have been up to [[theologian]]s and [[historian]]s." Lukin noted that "[[Winston Churchill]] once said: Stupidity is also a gift of God, but one mustn't misuse it."<ref name=dailymail-Lukin>{{cite news|title=Russian ombudsman warns Gita rulings should be up to experts|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/indiahome/indianews/article-2128403/Russian-ombudsman-warns-Gita-rulings-experts.html|newspaper=[[Daily Mail]]|date=11 April 2012|location=London|first=Dadan|last=Upadhyay}}</ref><ref name=IT-Lukin>{{cite news|title=Russian ombudsman warns on Gita rulings|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/russian-ombudsman-warns-on-gita-rulings/1/184131.html|newspaper=[[India Today]]|date=12 April 2012}}</ref><ref name=RIA-Lukin>{{cite news|title=Bhagavad Gita Texts Up for Experts to Judge - Russian Ombudsman|url=http://en.ria.ru/society/20120411/172744774.html|newspaper=[[RIA Novosti]]|date=11 April 2012}}</ref>
====Religions==== On December 28, 2011, the day the Tomsk court dismissed extremism charges against the ''Bhagavad Gita As It Is'', director of the Human Rights Center of the World Russian People's Council [[Roman Silantyev]] said that the examination of the ''Bhagavad Gita As It Is'' as extremist was accurate, and that "it has nothing to do with traditional Hinduism."
He also called Krishna devotees in Russia marginal pseudo-Hindu cult members with "extremely nasty reputation" and condemned their [[Hare Krishna Food for Life|charitable food distribution programs]] saying it was unacceptable for Orthodox, Muslim, Jews and Buddhist believers.<ref name=IFSil>{{cite news|title=Tomsk court didn't find "Bhagavad Gita" translation extremist|url=http://www.interfax-religion.com/?act=news&div=8953|accessdate=16 February 2012|date=28 December 2011|agency=[[Interfax]]}}</ref>
On January 18, 2012, a number of Russia's Islamic leaders denounced Hare Krishna followers in Russia as a "destructive cult" and called on the Russian authorities not to yield to the Indian pressure in regard of the proposed banning of the ''Bhagavad Gita As It''. [[Mufti]] Muhammedgali Huzin, head of All-Russian Muslim Board executive committee, said, "I believe that Russian authorities should be principally tough in the question and shouldn't give way to any provocations and pressure. I think that Russia can do without semiliterate interpretations of ancient epos". First deputy chairman of the Central Spiritual Board of Russian Muslims Mufti of Moscow and Russia's Central Region Albir Krganov proposed to "pay the debt" to Krishna devotees in Russia for their charitable food distribution by "delivering nutritious Halal canned beef to starving Krishna devotees of India. We are ready to personally distribute this meat to Russian Krishnaites".<ref name=IF-Mus>{{cite news|title=Russian Muslims believe Krishnaites a sect and ready to deliver them Halal meat|url=http://www.interfax-religion.com/?act=news&div=8986|accessdate=16 February 2012|date=18 January 2012|agency=[[Interfax]]}}</ref><ref name=RIR-Appeal>{{cite news|title=Siberian prosecutors make another attempt to ban Prabhupada’s Gita interpretation|url=http://indrus.in/articles/2012/01/26/siberian_prosecutors_make_another_attempt_to_ban_prabhupadas_gita_in_14630.html|accessdate=16 February 2012|newspaper=Russia & India Report|date=26 January 2012}}</ref> However, other all-Russia Islamic umbrella organizations rejected their statements as "fortunately" not representing the opinion of a majority of Russian Muslims of the issue.<ref name=RIR-Appeal />
On January 27, 2012, a group of Russian Orthodox Christian activists entered the premises of the Moscow Krishna temple and tried to hand the temple authorities a box of canned beef. The group claimed that their action was in retaliation for the burning of the Russian flag in India by Hindu fundamentalists protesting the proposed ban of the ''Bhagavad Gita As It Is'', which they called an "anti-Russian … disgraceful act" and "one of the steps in the unprecedented campaign of pressing on Russian court".<ref>{{cite news|title=Orthodox believers conveyed a batch of tinned stewed meat to Moscow Krishnaites in protest against burning Russian flag|url=http://www.interfax-religion.com/?act=news&div=9015|accessdate=16 February 2012|date=27 January 2012}}</ref>
On January 31, 2012, the head of the Traditional Buddhist Sangha of Russia Andrey Baljirov called the Indian authorities who asked the Russian government to help avert the proposed ban of the Bhagavad Gita As It Is "misinformed" and "exerting pressure" and spoke against the proposed construction of the Krishna temple in Moscow because "there are Buddhist followers in Moscow who do not have a temple yet".<ref name=IF-Bud>{{cite news|script-title=ru:В буддийской общине РФ выступают против строительства храма кришнаитов в Москве|trans-title=The Buddhist community of Russia spoke against the construction of Krishna temple in Moscow|url=http://www.interfax-religion.ru/?act=news&div=44000|accessdate=16 February 2012|date=31 January 2012|agency=[[Interfax]]|language=Russian}}</ref>

{{DISPLAYTITLE:''A Mathematician's Apology''}} {{Use British English|date=November 2012}} {{more footnotes|date=January 2012}} [[File:A Mathematician's Apology.pdf|thumb|Full text of the "A Mathematician's Apology" by G. H. Hardy.]] '''''A Mathematician's Apology''''' is a 1940 essay by British mathematician [[G. H. Hardy]]. It concerns the [[Mathematical beauty|aesthetics of mathematics]] with some personal content, and gives the layman an insight into the mind of a working [[mathematician]]. ==Summary== [[File:Ghhardy@72.jpg|thumb|left|In ''A Mathematician's Apology'', [[G. H. Hardy]] defined a set of criteria for mathematical beauty.]] In the book's title, Hardy uses the word "[[Apologetics|apology]]" in the sense of a formal justification or defence (as in [[Plato]]'s ''[[Apology (Plato)|Apology of Socrates]]''), not in the sense of a plea for forgiveness. Hardy felt the need to justify his life's work in mathematics at this time mainly for two reasons. Firstly, at age 62, Hardy felt the approach of old age (he had survived a heart attack in 1939) and the decline of his mathematical creativity and skills. By devoting time to writing the Apology, Hardy was admitting that his own time as a creative mathematician was finished. In his foreword to the 1967 edition of the book, [[C. P. Snow]] describes the Apology as "a passionate lament for creative powers that used to be and that will never come again". In Hardy's words, "Exposition, criticism, appreciation, is work for second-rate minds. [...] It is a melancholy experience for a professional mathematician to find himself writing about mathematics. The function of a mathematician is to do something, to prove new theorems, to add to mathematics, and not to talk about what he or other mathematicians have done." Secondly, at the start of the [[World War II]], Hardy, a committed [[pacifist]], wanted to justify his belief that mathematics should be pursued for its own sake rather than for the sake of its applications. He wanted to write a book in which he would explain his mathematical philosophy to the next generation of mathematicians; that would defend mathematics by elaborating on the merits of pure mathematics solely, without having to resort to the attainments of applied mathematics in order to justify the overall importance of mathematics; and that would inspire the upcoming generations of pure mathematicians. Hardy was an [[atheist]], and makes his justification not to [[God]] but to his fellow man. One of the main themes of the book is the beauty that mathematics possesses, which Hardy compares to painting and poetry.{{cite book |last1=King |first1=Jerry P. |title=The Art of Mathematics |date=1992 |publisher=Fawcett Columbine |isbn=0-449-90835-6 |pages=135–139}} For Hardy, the most beautiful mathematics was that which had no practical applications in the outside world ([[pure mathematics]]) and, in particular, his own special field of [[number theory]]. Hardy contends that if useful knowledge is defined as knowledge which is likely to contribute to the material comfort of mankind in the near future (if not right now), so that mere intellectual satisfaction is irrelevant, then the great bulk of higher mathematics is useless. He justifies the pursuit of pure mathematics with the argument that its very "uselessness" on the whole meant that it could not be misused to cause harm. On the other hand, Hardy denigrates much of the [[applied mathematics]] as either being "trivial", "ugly", or "dull", and contrasts it with "real mathematics", which is how he ranks the higher, pure mathematics. Hardy expounds by commenting about a phrase attributed to [[Carl Friedrich Gauss]] that "Mathematics is the queen of the sciences and number theory is the queen of mathematics." Some people believe that it is the extreme non-applicability of number theory that led Gauss to the above statement about number theory; however, Hardy points out that this is certainly not the reason. If an application of number theory were to be found, then certainly no one would try to dethrone the "queen of mathematics" because of that. What [[Carl Friedrich Gauss|Gauss]] meant, according to Hardy, is that the underlying concepts that constitute number theory are deeper and more elegant compared to those of any other branch of mathematics. Another theme is that mathematics is a "young man's game", so anyone with a talent for mathematics should develop and use that talent while they are young, before their ability to create original mathematics starts to decline in middle age. This view reflects Hardy's increasing depression at the wane of his own mathematical powers. For Hardy, real mathematics was essentially a creative activity, rather than an explanatory or expository one. ==Critiques== [[File:MathematiciansApology.jpg|thumb|First edition
(publ. [[Cambridge University Press]])]] Hardy's opinions were heavily influenced by the [[academia|academic]] culture of the universities of [[Cambridge]] and [[Oxford]] between [[World War I]] and [[World War II]]. Some of Hardy's examples seem unfortunate in retrospect. For example, he writes, "No one has yet discovered any warlike purpose to be served by the theory of numbers or relativity, and it seems unlikely that anyone will do so for many years." Since then number theory was used to crack German enigma codes and much later, figure prominently in [[public-key cryptography]].{{cite web|url=http://wayback.cecm.sfu.ca/personal/jborwein/apaper.pdf|title=Experimental mathematician Jonathan Borwein's comments on the Apology|publisher=}} However, Hardy's more prominent examples of elegant mathematical discoveries with no use (proofs of [[Euclid's theorem|the infinitude of primes]] and of [[Square root of 2|the irrationality of the square root of two]]) still hold up. The applicability of a mathematical concept is not the reason that Hardy considered applied mathematics somehow inferior to pure mathematics, though; it is the simplicity and prosiness that belong to applied mathematics that led him to describe them as he did. He considers that [[Rolle's theorem]] for example, though it is of some importance for [[calculus]], cannot be compared to the elegance and preeminence of the mathematics produced by [[Évariste Galois]] and other pure mathematicians. ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== *{{cite book |last=Hardy |first=G. H. |authorlink=G. H. Hardy |title=A Mathematician's Apology |publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]] |location=Cambridge |year=2004 |origyear=1940 |isbn=978-0-521-42706-7 |url=http://www.cambridge.org/catalogue/catalogue.asp?isbn=9780521427067}} * Mordell, L.
